greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Square array: A(row,col) = 2^(row-1) * 1+(2*A156552(col)) = A156552(A246278(row,col)), read by antidiagonals A(1,1), A(1,2), A(2,1), A(1,3), A(2,2), A(3,1), ...
comment: Shares with A135764 the property that A001511(n) = k for all terms n on row k and when going downwards in each column, terms grow by doubling.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1275; the first 50 antidiagonals of the array
Index entries for sequences that are permutations of the natural numbers
formula: A(row,col) = A135764(row, A005941(col)). [Is otherwise the same array as A135764, but the column positions have been permuted by A005941.]
A(row,col) = 2^(row-1) * ((2*A005941(col)) - 1) = 2^(row-1) * A005408(A156552(col)). [The above expands to this.]
As a composition of other permutations:
a(n) = A156552(A246278(n+1)). [When all three sequences are interpreted as one-dimensional sequences.]
example: The top left corner of the array:
xref: Differs from A135764 for the first time at n=22, where a(22) = 17, while A135764(22) = 13.
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Jan 03 2015
